reviewText: Before Greenlight and Early Access, this was the first piece of true shovelware I remember making it onto Steam. I was baffled as to how it actually made the cut. In a way, it was inspirational at the time; if something like this can get onto Steam, a guy like me can still dream, right?\n\nThere's no way to describe this game other than Crappy Geometry Wars". You mindlessly shoot hilariously unbalanced enemies that will fly at you from the sides of the screen and kill you before you can dodge. There's one broken achievement

reviewText:
In beginning of a boom of Indie games back in 2007 and 2008 it saw a number of casual games featuring graphics much like these. I am going to try to be respectful in this review, but this game is very bad and easily the worst I've played in a while.

First of all, Arcardia fails at the basic requirement of being functional software. I was not able to get a working controls either by keyboard or mouse or my gamepad. There is no help menu or even a key binding screen I can tell what keys I need to press. If you want to rebind the gamepad keys you need to edit the configuration file manually. If you want to rebind the keybaord keys then you may be out of luck as I saw no configuration file for the keyboard.

Gameplay wise, this game really wants to be Geometry Wars. It's to the point where it follows Geometry Wars home and Geometry wars should consider getting a restraining order. If this game was commercially successful the developers of Geometry Wars should consider legal action. You might think I'm exaggerating, but I played them side-by-side and the difference is uncanny. The only difference is that Geometry Wars actually works and is a lot more polished.

Acardia mimics Geometry Wars in the following ways; grid background, distortion effects, weapons and weapon progression, controls (best I can tell anyway, seeing as they didn't really work for me). Even much of the enemy AI is a mirror of Geometry Wars. It's even to the point where the same AI had the same rough shape and color as it's counterpart in Geometry Wars.

Just buy Geometry Wars if you don't already own it. It's much more polished and, most importantly, it actually works.

Score: 0/10

Summer Gaming Project Review:

reviewText:
I normally write more about games I am reviewing, but this one doesn't have much to talk about.  You're a triangle, and you shoot everything else in the universe to make fireworks appear until you mess up, touch something, and die.  That's pretty much it.  I'm fairly sure this is a first work of an aspiring programmer, and it's not terrible by any means, but it's just not worth really playing when there are better options out there for your cash and your time.

A quick look around the Steam Store will uncover more than a few games with more meat on their bones than this one.  Geometry Wars is an obvious one, as was Waves.  They have everything this game has, and more.

As a bright point, I did like the song track.  Emphasis on *THE* - it's the one in the trailer, and the only one, and it plays on loop.

reviewText: Arcadia looked like a budget game in the vein of Geometry Wars.  It even spoke of controller support back when I first bought it.  No such support existed at the time.  The developer claimed that he would fix it, but years later it doesn't work proper.  Even claiming partial controller support should count as a lie at this point.\n\nThe gameplay itself is rather bland, the visuals limited and the enemies lack any real diversity.  Even if you wish to play withj Mouse and Keyboard, this will likely bore you quickly.  It is, in my opinion, not worth the money (even in a sale), and a shame that the developer doesn't support his own work.

reviewText: This has been called Poor Man's Geometry Wars". It claims to have controller support.  It won't work with my wireless 360 controller. I don't have a logitech plug n' play controller anymore to test it with. The game is simple fun if you like arcade shooters. It has multiple modes and a few fun challenges.  This is great for dicking around on a netbook or wasting time. If you are looking for a game to sink hours and hours into then you should look somewhere else. If you are looking to screw around for a few hours on a netbook or laptop then come join the fun! The soundtrack is EPIC btw. The devs give instuctions to rip it from the game files and highly encourage it as well. Grab it when its on sale for clean arcade fun! ~PR0XIDIAN"

reviewText:
I see all these negative reviews complaining about lack of support and replay value, but I just want to say that despite its problems, this game is really fun for the 2$ I paid for it on sale.

The gameplay gets pretty intense, especially late in a round when tons of enemies are spawning, and it's an enjoyable challenge figuring out how to best kite and kill enemies and when to use bombs and such.

When you buy this game, be aware what you are paying for.  Arcadia is a casual shooter (As clearly mentioned) that is not meant to entertain you for long periods of time like other games.  This game is fun to play on and off when you don't have time for other deeper games, and it fulfills that goal excellently.  Don't buy this game if you are looking for a hardcore game to sink many hours into to beat or to become the best at it.

Whether this game is being actively updated or not isn't really relevant.  The game mechanics are solid and very entertaining in a casual situation, and I'm happy having given a one time payment of 2$ and receiving the end product I got.

One point that I want to given special mention to is the music in this game.  Hearing the music in this game is like half the experience of playing this game.  The dev of this game put together an awesome soundtrack for this game, which ends up making it extremely relaxing and enjoyable to play.  The music in this game is techno and trance from Newgrnds (Steam censors the full site name for some reason), so if you like that kind of music you'll probably enjoy this game

As the description clearly states, Arcadia is a fun
date: casual little shooter." And that's exactly what you get when you buy this game.  Hardcore gaming experience for hundreds of hours of evolving gameplay
recommended: no. Fun 2d bullet-hell shooter with awesome music that's worth a few bucks

reviewText:
Hidden gem. That's what I have to say.

You are Mr. Triangle.
You don't fit into this world as nothing else is a triangle (but some things are similarly pointy - I call those guys hypocrites).
Everything else doesn't like you.
You will explode if hit by something else.
Everything else wants to make you explode.
Mr. Triangle must use his latent psionic power to send yellow triangle bullets into everything else and kill them before he dies himself.
Mr. Triangle must also move around so he can avoid everything else that is out to kill him.
When Mr. Triangle dies, he loses part of his Triangle Power. When all the Triangle Power goes away, it's game over for him.

It's a £1 game, really. Extremely simple but pretty damn fun.

SAVE A TRIANGLE BY HELPING HIM TODAY.

reviewText:
Arcadia is a top-down Retro styled shooter in the vein of Geometry Wars and its many clones. To many, this game is just a clone of GeoWars at first glance, but a look beyond reveals quite a different truth...

The game is HIGHLY evolutionary, and the developer is VERY involved in the forums and is commited to expanding and improving the game in every way. It has recieved multiple engine updates and so far one complete engine re-write that resulted in an improvement in performance of over an order of magnitude on many setups.

The enemy AI is absurdly challenging and the game is very demanding and skill-based. That does not mean it is not accessible, but it is not something you can pick up and score 1M or above like GeoWars. Getting to 250k is an achievement, and once you get there you feel the need to walk around the house with both arms raised up in a victory pose.

There is development covering new game modes, enemies, design elements, and performance improvements. Get this game NOW.

reviewText: Arcadia is quite possibly the laziest attempt at an indie game I have ever seen. Let me tell you something about indie games, they must be artistic. Nothing about arcadia is Artistic. If Arcadia is artistic, then I can get a piece of graph paper with a drawn triangle in the middle and call that art. The musical score is a techno beat that repeat endlessly to the point where I just mute the dam game sounds effects and music. I swear I’ve seen middle school children who can design/program more advance games than Arcadia on visual basic. I haven’t even been playing for one hour, and I’m almost through with this game. Not sure if I will even bother getting the rest of the achievements. Oh ya, the leaderboards are broken, doesn’t upload high scores.

reviewText:
Broken. Don't waste your time.

There is a configuration screen outside the game, and an in-game options screen. They do not agree on what are the actual settings.

If you have a gamepad plugged, the game will use the gamepad even if you disable it in the configuration. And the XBox 360 gamepad does not work correctly (the mapping of analog axes in-game is broken). The only way to play with the mouse is by unplugging the gamepad.

Broken achievements.

Un-engaging gameplay, most of the time you will die before having time to react.

reviewText: Initial impressions aren't good. Arcadia is a game that feels like a student finals project that completely apes the visuals and mechanics of the far-superior game Geometry Wars.   If Arcadia had come first the comparison would be better because by itself it's entertaining in a do-it-yourself homebrew venture, ie: there's nothing terribly *bad* about it.  Still there's no escaping the comparison: next to Geometry Wars, Arcadia's controls and movement flow aren't nearly so finessed (I couldn't get duel stick control pad to function properly), the player character and enemies are tiny and not very artistically distinctive, the music isn't very compelling, and the visual flair is a throwback to 1993 without much in the way of modern razzle-dazzle.\n\nMaybe the game gets better the longer you play it but after spending 20 minutes on it I don't think I'll be trying to play it much ever again.
